subject: Empty exception handlers and Checkstyle
msgSnippet: ... Interesting... you can t tell Checkstyle, Let empty catch blocks go if the exception variable is one of the following: ... ? -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
messageBody:
John Smith wrote:
> --- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> >
> > Yes, empty catch clauses are okay if the developer
> > is clearly showing it's
> > expected. I use "ignore" myself:
> >
> > catch(NoObjectFoundException ignore)
> > {
> > // Ignore
> > }
>
> Thats also what Joshua Bloch suggests in his famous
> book "Effective Java Programming Language Guide".
>
> He writes that empty catch blocks should be very
> seldom. If they can't be avoided, he suggests to write
> a comment in the catch block.
>
> This applies to JUnit tests too in my eyes.
>
> In my eyes, empty catch blocks are legal in certain
> situations. No Checkstyle tool can be smart enough to
> know if it is legal in a certain situation or not to
> leave a catch block empty with just a comment. But
> these tools always warn whenever a rule has been
> broken, like "empty block". For Checkstyle there is
> just black or white, nothing in between in this case.

Interesting... you can't tell Checkstyle, "Let empty catch blocks go if
the exception variable is one of the following: ..."?
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
